data.title: Cannot debug Electron app on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0 (also latest 1.3.0-insiders)
- OS Version: Windows 10 (build 10586.318)

Steps to Reproduce:

Using the following `launch.json` configuration:

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/src/scripts/main.ts",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/src",
            "preLaunchTask": "compile",
            "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/electron",
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--enable-logging"
            ],
            "env": {},
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            // win32 & linux
            "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/src/bin/resources/app"
            // darwin
            //"outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/src/bin/Electron.app/Contents/Resources/app"
        },
        {
            "name": "Attach",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 5858,
            "address": "localhost",
            "restart": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null,
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": null
        }
    ]
}
```

I'm getting the following error message 
`Cannot launch debug target (spawn ${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/electron ENOENT)`
when trying to debug, either via F5 or directly from Debugger window.

If I set `"externalConsole": true` then the Debugger starts and opens an external console.
This behavior is not noticeable on Linux or OS X (setting `externalConsole` either to false or true works as intended).

data.title: Indentation conversion commands adjusted
data.body:
- If there is a selection, then the conversion is only applied to that,
  otherwise to the complete text.
- It changes not only the beginning of each line but every occureance

resolves #6277 and #7415

data.title: TypeScript: Curly braces in angle brackets breaks syntax highlighting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider (7d56f33e508930d3727064481a7525344a227f10)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Enter following code (from https://github.com/aspnet/JavaScriptServices/blob/master/templates/ReactReduxSpa/ClientApp/components/Counter.tsx):

``` typescript
const provider = provide(
  (state: ApplicationState) => state.weatherForecasts, // Select which part of global state maps to this component
  WeatherForecastsState.actionCreators                 // Select which action creators should be exposed to this component
).withExternalProps<{ params: RouteParams }>();          // Also include a 'params' property on WeatherForecastProps
type WeatherForecastProps = typeof provider.allProps;
export default provider.connect(FetchData);
```
1. See that syntax highlighting stops working after `<{ params: RouteParams }>()`:
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/594564/15991011/9fbc26d8-30a5-11e6-9472-afab8e3724ec.png)

data.title: Certain TSX files break "Format Code"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider (7d56f33e508930d3727064481a7525344a227f10) - OS Version: OS X 10.11.5 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Download https://github.com/aspnet/JavaScriptServices/blob/master/templates/ReactReduxSpa/ClientApp/components/Home.tsx and open it in VSCode 2. Indent something so it is mis-aligned 3. Do "Format Code" action 4. See that nothing happens 5. See that "Format Code" has also stopped working for any other JS/TS-files in the workspace Only fix is to restart VSCode (and not try to format code in Home.tsx) No idea what makes this file special; here is the content: ``` typescript import * as React from 'react'; export default class Home extends React.Component { public render() { return

Hello, World!

Welcome to your new single-page application, built with:

  • ASP.NET Core and C# for cross-platform server-side code
  • React, Redux, and TypeScript for client-side code
  • Webpack for building and bundling client-side resources
  • Bootstrap for layout and styling

To help you get started, we've also set up:

  • Client-side navigation. For example, click Counter then Back to return here.
  • Webpack dev middleware. In development mode, there's no need to run the webpack build tool. Your client-side resources are dynamically built on demand. Updates are available as soon as you modify any file.
  • Hot module replacement. In development mode, you don't even need to reload the page after making most changes. Within seconds of saving changes to files, rebuilt CSS and React components will be injected directly into your running application, preserving its live state.
  • Efficient production builds. In production mode, development-time features are disabled, and the webpack build tool produces minified static CSS and JavaScript files.
  • Server-side prerendering. To optimize startup time, your React application is first rendered on the server. The initial HTML and state is then transferred to the browser, where client-side code picks up where the server left off.
; } } ```

function main() {

data.title: Weird autoformatting of es2015 import statements
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider 2016-06-09T21:54:01.520Z
- OS Version: Mac OSX 10.11.5

Single line import statements get formatted like objects. This only happens with javascript not with typescript. Typescript seems to skip formatting of import statements.

Before saving:

``` js
import {compose} from 'redux';
```

after saving:

``` js
import {
    compose
} from 'redux';
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a .js file and paste `import {compose} from 'redux';`
2. Press save -> code gets formatted

data.title: Can't pass parameters to the program when launching within VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.1.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04
- dotnet version: 1.0.0-preview1-002702

Additional information:
- Commit def9e32467ad6e4f48787d38caf190acbfee5880
- Date 2016-05-13T13:38:00.094Z
- Shell 0.37.6
- Renderer 49.0.2623.75
- Node 5.10.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Created a simple Program which writes "Hello World" into the console
2. In launch.json added in "configurations.args" a value. Something like `"args": ["Foo"],`
3. Build and (try to)  run by hitting F5. the result is 

``` javascript
{
  "name": "Microsoft.ApplicationInsights.74cc1c9e3e6e4d05b3fcdde9101d0254.Event",
  "time": "2016-06-12T05:12:50.6665084Z",
  "iKey": "74cc1c9e-3e6e-4d05-b3fc-dde9101d0254",
  "tags": {
    "ai.session.id": "ab608094-fe31-4978-8556-169002602a00",
    "ai.device.osVersion": "ubuntu",
    "ai.internal.sdkVersion": "2.0.0.30671"
  },
  "data": {
    "baseType": "EventData",
    "baseData": {
      "ver": 2,
      "name": "/home/FooBar/MyProjects/DotNet/ConsoleApps/ConsolePassingParameter/bin/Debug/netcoreapp1.0/ConsolePassingParameter.dllFoo",
      "properties": {
        "OS Version": "14.04",
        "OS Platform": "Linux",
        "Runtime Id": "ubuntu.14.04-x64",
        "Product Version": "1.0.0-preview1-002702"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

When I start the program in terminal `dotnet /home/FooBar/MyProjects/DotNet/ConsoleApps/ConsolePassingParameter/bin/Debug/netcoreapp1.0/ConsolePassingParameter.dll Foo` the program runs without problems. The parameters are passed correctly

From VSCode:
When I don't use `"args": []` in Launch.json, the program runs without problems too.

data.title: Task running indicator stays spinning
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Only reproduces intermittently... I will update if I can find a hard repro case...

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode in a project directory with a `tasks.json` containing a build script
2. Press Ctrl+Alt+B

Observed: even after the script seems to have completed, the spinning indicator sometimes continues to spin indefinitely.

data.title: taskName from tasks.json appended as a parameter when executed
data.body:
First, I have to echo previous bugs that comment that the documentation at https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558 is **not** helpful in understanding the architecture of VSCode's tasks feature.   Second, I suggest that lack of reference style documentation on the schema for `tasks.json` masks design flaws, particularly when `tasks.json` contains multiple tasks.   
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Bug:  It seems surprising behavior that `taskName` of the individual task selected is automatically inserted as an argument when running the command.    It's best illustrated with the following `tasks.json` which attempts to use `npm run prepublish` as the build command.

```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "npm",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": [],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "tasks": [
        {
        "taskName": "build",
        "isBuildCommand": true,
        "args": ["run", "prepublish"],
        "problemMatcher": ["$tsc"]
        }
    ]
}
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a project with  `.vscode/tasks.json` set as above, and open in VSCode
2. press Ctrl+Alt+B.

Expected: I expected this to run the following command:

```
npm run prepublish
```

Observed result: the `taskName` of `build` is unexpectedly inserted as an argument in the command, resulting in the following error:

```
npm ERR! Windows_NT 10.0.10586
npm ERR! argv "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node.exe" "C:\\Users\\Burt_\\AppData\\Roaming\\npm\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "build" "run" "prepublish"
npm ERR! node v4.4.5
npm ERR! npm  v3.9.5
npm ERR! path c:\my\ts-npm-module\run\package.json
npm ERR! code ENOENT
npm ERR! errno -4058
npm ERR! syscall open
...
```

Workaround: this version of `tasks.json` seems to work:

```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "npm",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["run"],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "tasks": [
        {
        "taskName": "prepublish",
        "isBuildCommand": true,
        "args": [],
        "problemMatcher": ["$tsc"]
        }
    ]
}
```

Related Question:  is the 'version' element of tasks.json intended to allow semantic versioning of the schema used?  Is there any version-specific documentation on these schemas?

data.title: "Open Folder" opens base directory, not the specified directory

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 12.04

"Open Folder" opens the base directory, not the directory navigated to. For example, attempting to open myhome/src/foofolder, vscode displays files in myhome. Not knowing how to locate and defeat the offending misconfiguration, this has rendered vscode effectively useless.

This issue began occurring after I opened two concurrent instances of vscode, whether coincidence or not is unclear. This issue appears to be sufficiently different than #2115 to warrant a new issue, since this issue began a week or so after installing and using vscode successfully.

data.title: Terminal text shifts to the left when scrolling up
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Insider Preview build 14352.rs1_Release.160522-1930

[I am using angular-cli's ng--help function for this case.](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch VS Code
2. Open Terminal
3. ls
4. dir
5. ng --help
6. Scroll up

Result:  All the text in the terminal shifts to the left, and the terminal becomes stuck that way.  In my gif, i somehow got it back, but once i scrolled up it broke again.

Here is my dev tools console at startup.  It does not change when this error occurs.

data.title: csproj support?
data.body:
Some pretty fantastic, and a couple humorous events events in the Microsoft timeline, to build my case:
- November 20, 1985 - Windows 1.0 is released and changed the world
- August 24, 1995 - Windows 95 was released and changed the world
- Sometime in 1997 - Boston is born, later to be released as Visual Studio, and changed the world
- January 1999 - Simple Managed C (SMC) was started
- September 5 2000 - Balmer announces his love for this company and changed the world https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=04FOUQpnGsc
- January 2002 - SMC (now C#) v1.0 is released and changed the world
- March 6 2008 - "Developers, Developers, Developers!" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oioj24KQRvM and changed the world
- March 18 2014 - `Roslyn.Says("Hello World"); //and changed the world` https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/commit/3611ed35610793e814c8aa25715aa582ec08a8b6
- November 13, 2015 - VSCode is public! https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/8f35cc4768393b25468416829e980d7550619fb1 and changed the world
- Currently - Visual Studio and VSCode are advertised together - https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/visual-studio-homepage-vs.aspx and visual studio code is changing the world

So much went into the creation of VSCode and I admire the work that has lead up to it, but VSCode apparently has no means of running asp.net csproj projects. Rather than create a new launch.json file in order to do so, shouldn't there just be an import capability?

If the reply you are currently thinking of starts with: "Well this is open source software, scratch your own itch", does that mean that Microsoft is essentially abandoning the existing countless C# projects?  Every event in the timeline above (even the Ballmer ones) starting at 1999 and afterward involved either directly or indirectly C#, it'd be nice if we could simply import our existing projects.

After all: "developers, developers, developers"

data.title: [Feat] Add project support
data.body:
One of the nice things Sublime has over VS Code is workspaces and projects, Sublime allows to set a workspace with configs for it, as well as saving those to load the workspace later.

However the feature i want to reccomend is projects, Sublime is great in that regard since the projects are kind like the workspaces, just that they are remembered and is very easy to change between projects with a few keystrokes.

Currently VS Code doesn't have those concepts so i'm forced to open the top folder that contains all the projects i'm working / had worked on, that's a lot of folders to see, i like clean development environment so it would be a great addition to be able to set projects with just the folders or projects i need, and easily change between projects.

Lastly when i mean change between projects i don't mean like the workspaces of Sublime that we need to change by searching the workspace config file in the root of the workspace or wherever you saved it, i mean like Sublime projects that remember the last ones that were used and with a keyboard shortcut allow to see a list of those and quick change between them.

**Sumary:**
- Add support for multiple base folders in same window.
- Add support for a project manager that allows to save the previous item as a project for easy dev env restoration.
- Add an easy way to switch between projects recently used.

I think this would make VS Code even better, any thoughts about this?

data.title: Electron Helper draws 100% CPU
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start VS Code
2. Open project folder

Electron Helper process draws 100% CPU as soon as I open a project folder. GUI is still responsive though.

Somehow I suspect that this has something to do with the git pane (**the project is managed by mercurial, not by git!**):
- Open the project -> CPU usage goes to 100% for ~3 minutes
- Git icon shows badge "99+" -> CPU usage falls down to a reasonable level
- After some seconds, CPU usage rises again to 100% for ~4 minutes
- CPU usage is again at a reasonable level

Then, after a make any modification to a file, the git badge switches to a clock icon and after a few seconds it starts again drawing 100% CPU.

data.title: Terminal doesn't respond after run an infinite bucle program
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run a normal program, use "`Ctrl + c`" to close it, it works!
2. Run a program with an infinite bucle
    `while(true){print("bucle");}`
3. Use "`Ctrl + c`" to close it, it doesn't work, program is still working
